M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, which authorizes modification of custody and visitation orders upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where such modification serves the best interests of the children.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20 governs modification of custody and visitation orders for unmarried parents, applying the same “best interests” and “material change in circumstances” standard.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 31 & 31A.proposition: define the legal framework for custody and shared parenting determinations.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas concerns an initial divorce judgment awarding custody and authorizing removal of the children to Greece, not a subsequent modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time. The court analyzes best interests and the ‘real advantage’ standard for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but does not discuss or apply the legal standard for modifying an existing custody or visitation order due to changed circumstances. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about modification when parenting time materially changes.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint custody context and articulates the ‘best interests of the child’ standard for deciding whether to permit removal. Although the father did file a complaint for modification seeking sole physical custody, the SJC does not discuss or apply any rule about when a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time justifies modifying a custody order. The case is about the standard for authorizing out-of-state removal, not about modification of custody upon a material change in parenting time capacity, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "When the mother informed the father of her intention to move to New Hampshire, the father refused to consent to removal of the children from the Commonwealth and filed a complaint for modification of the divorce decree in the Probate and Family Court seeking, among other things, sole physical custody and a temporary order enjoining the mother from removing the children from the Commonwealth.... After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court."

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The Appeals Court explicitly discusses the standard for modifying an existing custody order under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and reaffirms that a custody modification requires a "material and substantial change in circumstances" of the parties and that modification must be in the child’s best interests. In doing so, it cites and aligns itself with prior SJC and Appeals Court decisions (e.g., Hersey, Fuller, Tolos, Delmolino), thereby recognizing and applying the long‑standing rule that when circumstances affecting a parent’s exercise of custody/parenting change materially, the custody order may be modified. Although the case focuses on relocation, its custody‑modification analysis directly supports the stated proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not support the claimed proposition. The opinion is not a modification case based on a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time; it is an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). The SJC explicitly declines to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification under § 20, finding that issue waived, so it does not affirm or discuss any rule about modifying existing orders when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). ... It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20…"

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2011.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2011.support_reasoning: The opinion is about relocation and paternity under G.L. c. 209C, focusing on the mother’s right, as the sole legal parent before adjudication of paternity, to relocate without permission. It does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time; indeed, the discussion concerns the judge’s lack of authority to order the mother back to Massachusetts and the need to respect the status quo. Therefore, it does not establish or affirm the proposition about modifying custody when parenting time materially changes.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2011.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for initial custody determinations and the best-interests analysis, but it does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time. The case is about the original allocation of physical custody following dissolution of the domestic partnership, not about later modification of a prior custody judgment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition regarding modification when parenting time circumstances materially change.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ … The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’ … There was no abuse of discretion in determining that primary physical custody of Jill should be with the plaintiff.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case discusses custody, visitation, and the court’s authority to suspend a parent’s visitation rights when necessary to protect the child’s best interests, but it does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time. The opinion affirms an initial divorce judgment awarding sole custody and imposing a one-year cessation of contact, rather than analyzing standards for later modification in response to changed circumstances. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody orders when parenting time ability materially changes.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: However, the strong expression of public policy by our Legislature that a child’s welfare must be the paramount concern when a judge determines custody, see G. L. c. 208, §§ 31 and 31A, and G. L. c. 209A, § 3(d), means that a judge is authorized not only to order sole legal and physical custody with one parent when it serves the best interests of the child, … but also that a judge is authorized to impose conditions and restrictions on and to suspend any visitation by the other parent when it is determined that visitation would not be in the best interests of the child.

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The case involves custody and visitation determinations and acknowledges that such orders are subject to future modification, but it does not hold or discuss that a ‘material change’ in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time is the trigger or standard for modifying an existing custody order. The opinion merely cites G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30 and other cases for the general proposition that custody orders are modifiable; it does not elaborate on or adopt a ‘material change in circumstances’ test with respect to parenting time. Thus it provides only background authority for modifiability, not for the specific proposition stated.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion. **As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930).**”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have long recognized that when a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time materially changes, the Court may modify the existing custody order.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an appeal from an initial custody adjudication and a remand for further findings on domestic violence; it does not involve or discuss modification of an existing custody order based on a later material change in a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time. The court focuses on required findings regarding domestic violence in making or justifying a custody award, not on the standard or authority for post‑judgment modification when circumstances change. Thus it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about modification of existing custody orders.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."
